column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Be a Handyman
#Text=Have you ever felt powerless when faced with a vexing home repair problem ?
#Text=Were you left in awe by a handyman who capably did what needed to be done ?
#Text=You can be that awe-inspiring person .
#Text=That 's right , " person " .
#Text=You do n't have to be a man to be a handyman .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Remember : safety first !
#Text=You want to be a handyman , not a dead man .
#Text=Consider , for example , that many of the warnings that appear in manuals , on labels or on tools are rooted in someone else 's misfortune or stupidity .
#Text=Be sure to read and heed them .
#Text=Putting safety first is your first step in doing the job right and presenting a professional image - even if it 's just to yourself .
#Text=" Safety first " will mean different things in different situations , but some basic rules apply to nearly every job .
#Text=For example , a well-lit workspace is fundamental .
#Text=It will help you see otherwise hidden or obscure dangers .
#Text=You 're also not likely to do well at a job that you ca n't see well .
#Text=Have the right tools for the job .
#Text=The first tools you need are those that make the job safe , such as a face-mask or respirator when working with insulation or toxic dust .
#Text=Using the wrong tool ( e.g. , a shaky chair instead of a stable ladder ) or using a tool improperly invites injury to yourself and can compromise the quality of the job you 're doing .
#Text=Get the right tools and use them the right way .
#Text=Never buy a tool you do n't need , but always buy ( or rent or borrow ) the tool required by the job .
#Text=This makes for a simple solution to the question " What tools should I have ? "
#Text=It 's the tools that you need to do the job safely and correctly .
#Text=Educate yourself .
#Text=Learn all you can before starting a job .
#Text=Go on-line ( see below for helpful links ) .
#Text=Go to the library .
#Text=Read the instructions/the manual .
#Text=Find people who have done that type of job and ask what they did right and what they would do differently if they knew then what they know now .
#Text=Check with your local government 's building permits office re any needed permits or other requirements .
#Text=Just as " an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure " , an hour of education is worth a day of doing it over .
#Text=Be open to new approaches .
#Text=Never assume that you know the best way to do anything ; arrogant people are closed to learning .
#Text=Be open to ideas and insights from any source - including a spouse , a child , and a customer once you get to that point .
#Text=The less experienced they are , the more likely it is that you 'll hear something you would never have considered .
#Text=Allow enough time .
#Text=The time you think the job will take is likely based more on your fond hopes than unforgiving reality .
#Text=Jobs often involve complications that appear only once you 're underway .
#Text=On those rare and splendid occasions when the job goes faster than planned , you wo n't think that you misjudged - you 'll be too absorbed in contemplating your genius .
#Text=Having planned enough time , be sure to take it .
#Text=Carpenters say , e.g. , to " measure twice and cut once . "
#Text=What that really means is take the time to carefully measure .
#Text=Have a good work ethic .
#Text=A job worth doing is worth doing well .
#Text=It 's also a requirement , as with the electrical code mandate that all work be done " in a workmanlike manner . "
#Text=Your name is going to be on that job , literally or figuratively , so make a good name for yourself .
#Text=A good work ethic applies to every aspect and every stage of a job , and it always appears in the final results .
#Text=For example , when hanging a framed picture on the middle of a wall , do n't " gaze and guess " at the center point of the wall -- use a tape measure and pencil to mark it .
#Text=If you 're replacing a light switch , use a level to align the switch when tightening the screws so as to avoid a lopsided look once the cover plate is attached .
#Text=Clean up .
#Text=The job 's not over until the dirt is swept up , the tools cleaned and put away , and the trash removed .
#Text=This is a hallmark of a real pro .

#Text=Plan ahead to ease that clean-up by , e.g. , using drop-cloths , clearing the work area of objects that may get dirty , sealing-off the work area to prevent dust from spreading , or using fans to ventilate airborne dust out the window .
#Text=Celebrate when it 's over !
#Text=You 've done your best and your best deserves a pat on the back , even if it 's from your own arm twisted over your shoulder .
#Text=Was the job absolutely perfect ?
#Text=That 's rarely the case .
#Text=The point is , you did what amounts to a hand-made job , and hand-made is bound to have slight imperfections .
#Text=So do n't obsess or slam yourself for what may be apparent only to yourself .
#Text=Also , " celebrate when it 's over " implies not celebrating ( with intoxicants ) while you 're working , which brings us back to the opening and most important point : Safety First !
